title: Standard Application Layer Protocol
descrption: Adversaries may communicate using a common, standardized application layer protocol such as HTTP, HTTPS, SMTP, or DNS to avoid detection by blending in with existing traffic. Commands to the remote system, and often the results of those commands, will be embedded within the protocol traffic between the client and server.For connections that occur internally within an enclave (such as those between a proxy or pivot node and other nodes), commonly used protocols are RPC, SSH, or RDP.
Data Sources: Packet capture, Netflow/Enclave netflow, Process use of network, Malware reverse engineering, Process monitoring

related.Name: 3PARA RAT
related.Description: 3PARA RAT uses HTTP for command and control.[20]

related.Name: 4H RAT
related.Description: 4H RAT uses HTTP for command and control.[20]

related.Name: ADVSTORESHELL
related.Description: ADVSTORESHELL connects to port 80 of a C2 server using Wininet API.[64]

related.Name: Agent Tesla
related.Description: Agent Tesla has used HTTP and SMTP for C2 communications.[37][38]

related.Name: APT18
related.Description: APT18 uses HTTP and DNS for C2 communications.[160]

related.Name: APT19
related.Description: APT19 used HTTP for C2 communications. APT19 also used an HTTP malware variant to communicate over HTTP for C2.[152][153]

related.Name: APT28
related.Description: APT28 used SMTP as a communication channel in various implants, initially using self-registered Google Mail accounts and later compromised email servers of its victims. Later implants such as CHOPSTICK use a blend of HTTP and other legitimate channels, depending on module configuration.[42]

related.Name: APT32
related.Description: APT32 has used JavaScript that communicates over HTTP or HTTPS to attacker controlled domains to download additional frameworks. The group has also used email for C2 via an Office macro. The group's backdoor can also exfiltrate data by encoding it in the subdomain field of DNS packets.[165][98][166][167]

related.Name: APT33
related.Description: APT33 has used HTTP for command and control.[180]

related.Name: APT37
related.Description: APT37 uses HTTPS to conceal C2 communications.[164]

related.Name: APT38
related.Description: APT38 used a backdoor, QUICKRIDE, to communicate to the C2 server over HTTP and HTTPS.[158]

related.Name: APT41
related.Description: APT41 used DNS for C2 communications. [183]

related.Name: BACKSPACE
related.Description: BACKSPACE uses HTTP as a transport to communicate with its command server.[17]

related.Name: BADNEWS
related.Description: BADNEWS establishes a backdoor over HTTP.[5]

related.Name: BadPatch
related.Description: BadPatch uses HTTP and SMTP for C2.[94]

related.Name: Bankshot
related.Description: Bankshot uses HTTP for command and control communication.[65]

related.Name: BBSRAT
related.Description: BBSRAT uses GET and POST requests over HTTP or HTTPS for command and control to obtain commands and send ZLIB compressed data back to the C2 server.[9]

related.Name: Bisonal
related.Description: Bisonal uses HTTP for C2 communications.[96]

related.Name: BlackEnergy
related.Description: BlackEnergy communicates with its C2 server over HTTP.[86]

related.Name: BONDUPDATER
related.Description: BONDUPDATER can use DNS and TXT records within its DNS tunneling protocol for command and control.[130]

related.Name: Brave Prince
related.Description: Some Brave Prince variants have used South Korea's Daum email service to exfiltrate information, and later variants have posted the data to a web server via an HTTP post command.[113]

related.Name: BRONZE BUTLER
related.Description: BRONZE BUTLER malware has used HTTP for C2.[29]

related.Name: BUBBLEWRAP
related.Description: BUBBLEWRAP can communicate using HTTP or HTTPS.[59]

related.Name: Cannon
related.Description: Cannon uses SMTP/S and POP3/S for C2 communications by sending and receiving emails.[25]

related.Name: Carbanak
related.Description: The Carbanak malware communicates to its command server using HTTP with an encrypted payload.[21]

related.Name: Cardinal RAT
related.Description: Cardinal RAT is downloaded using HTTP over port 443.[105]

related.Name: ChChes
related.Description: ChChes communicates to its C2 server over HTTP and embeds data within the Cookie HTTP header.[46][47]

related.Name: China Chopper
related.Description: China Chopper's server component executes code sent via HTTP POST commands.[73]

related.Name: CHOPSTICK
related.Description: Various implementations of CHOPSTICK communicate with C2 over HTTP, SMTP, and POP3.[110]

related.Name: CloudDuke
related.Description: One variant of CloudDuke uses HTTP and HTTPS for C2.[12]

related.Name: Cobalt Group

related.Description: Cobalt Strike uses a custom command and control protocol that is encapsulated in HTTP, HTTPS, or DNS. In addition, it conducts peer-to-peer communication over Windows named pipes encapsulated in the SMB protocol. All protocols use their standard assigned ports.[2]

related.Name: NETEAGLE
related.Description: NETEAGLE will attempt to detect if the infected host is configured to a proxy. If so, NETEAGLE will send beacons via an HTTP POST request; otherwise it will send beacons via UDP/6000. NETEAGLE will also use HTTP to download resources that contain an IP address and Port Number pair to connect to for further C2. Adversaries can also use NETEAGLE to establish an RDP connection with a controller over TCP/7519.[17]

Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level.
